awd_titl_txt: Ligand and Catalyst Designs for Stereocontrolled Ring Expansion Polymerization Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Adam S. Veige of the University of Florida is supported by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Division of Chemistry to develop catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic polymers, a class of polymers which is growing in fundamental and industrial interest due to the unique properties resulting from their cyclic, rather than linear, structure. The focus of this project is on the development of catalysts based on abundant transition metals and specially designed ligands. The objective is to develop optimized catalysts that not only produce cyclic polymers efficiently and selectively, but also execute the polymerization in a very regular fashion. Cyclic polymers which are free from linear impurities are highly desirable for special industrial applications, such as components of shock-mitigating composite materials and motor and jet engine oils. During the course of conducting this research, students develop cross-disciplinary skills in inorganic, organometallic, polymer and material chemistry to meet the demands of an increasingly specialized technological workplace. The project continues the educational outreach program that culminates in an annual Center for Catalysis-Chemistry Day at the Oaks Mall.  The event is intended to raise public awareness of research in and the importance of catalysis and to inspire the next generation of scientists. 

Catalysts based on complexes of abundant transition metals with tri- and tetra-anionic pincer ligands are developed.  Unique approaches to preparing cyclic polymers with these catalysts are explored.  Alkylidyne and tethered alkylidene catalysts are developed for the stereospecific ring expansion metathesis polymerization (REMP) of cyclic alkenes and for the polymerization of alkynes to produce macrocyclic polyalkynes.  The design of ligands and catalysts is based on fundamental electronic/structure property relationships.  Control of the molecular weight of the polymers is accomplished by tuning ligand properties to create rapidly initiating species.  The products, cyclic polymers which are free from linear impurities, are highly desirable for a variety of applications, such as components of shock-mitigating composite materials and motor and jet engine oils.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
A significant challenge in modern polymer chemistry is the efficient and controlled synthesis of polymers with unique shapes. Cyclic polymers have a ring-like topology and therefore have no chain ends, unlike their linear counterparts. Because of their topology, cyclic polymers, in comparison to linear versions possess different physical properties in both bulk and solution. Despite having these unique properties, most commercially available polymers have a linear topology, and the synthesis of cyclic polymers is somewhat limited to research laboratories. Catalysts developed during during this project can now polymerize norbornene to give stereoregular cyclic polynorbornene. Linear polynorbornene, commercially known as Norsorex?, is an integral material in a wide range of commercial products because of its good damping properties and durability. These properties make it particularly useful in tires, noise and vibration damping materials used in railways, and personal protection gear. The hydrogenated version, commercially known by its tradename ZEONEX?, is used for optical applications such as lenses, while ZEONOR? is used as a general-purpose transparent engineering plastic. The worldwide market for Cyclic Olefin Polymers (COP) is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of roughly 2.3% over the next five years, reaching a value of 1690 million US dollars in 2024 from 1470 million US dollars in 2019, according to a Global Info Research (GIR) study. Producing cyclic polynorbornene on a large scale is now synthetically possible using catalysts developed during this project.

 

Linear polyphenylacetylenes have potential in future applications as functional materials that possess unique properties including electrical conductivity, paramagnetic susceptibility, optical nonlinearity, photoconductivity, gas permeability, liquid-crystallinity, and chain-helicity. During the course of this project the PI and his students discovered new catalysts that produce cyclic versions of these polymers. More importantly, mechanistic studies unraveled key intermediates in the catalytic cycle that will enable tuning of future catalyst designs. These discoveries open immense opportunities to explore the aforementioned materials properties. Moreover, not only can the team now synthesize large cyclic polyenes, the new catalysts are some of the most active catalyst. Results from this project open the opportunity for the US to lead in the area of cyclic polymers. By simple choice of alkyne or combination of alkyne monomers it is now possible to access cyclic polymers of high purity, variable molecular weight, rapidly, and on potential commercial scales for the first time.

 

An important outcome from the project centers on technology transfer. Five patent applications were filed on the catalysts and materials discovered during the project period. Another major accomplishments during the previous project years was the graduation and job placement of two Ph.D. students. In total this grant supports/supported the research endeavors of six nine graduate students, three undergraduate students. Three Ph.D. students continuing their studies will receive degree as a direct result of participating in this project, thus adding to the next generation of highly-skilled chemists.

 

Finally, raising public awareness of the chemical sciences and inspiring the next generation of chemists through a Center for Catalysis Chemistry Day at the Mall is an ongoing educational outreach project executed by the nominee under this NSF project. Designed as an interactive, fun, and educational experience for students in grades K?12, local teachers, and parents. Now in its 15th year, this event continues to grow with the support of the NSF. In recent years approximately 400-500 children and their parents attended the event; casual onlookers number in the thousands. Each year about fifty graduate and undergraduate students exhibit ~25 chemistry demonstrations. This outreach program was designed by carefully considering data established by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) and the National Institute of Standards and Technology for effective communication of science and technology to the public: 1) illustrated both the process and the product of science, 2) involved scientists in a substantial way, 3) used interactivity to bring science to life, 4) related science to the everyday environment, 5) used face to face methods, and 6) reached out beyond the science-attentive public.

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2020
Modified by: Adam S Veige
